item.title: Draft Epstein Indictment Accused Him of Crimes Against More Than a Dozen Girls
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein, who ended up pleading to a much lesser state charge, told one victim that bad things could happen to her if she talked, the 2007 document said.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2019, the F.B.I. announced new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.

item.title: Police Report Backs Activist’s Account in Clash With ICE Agent Near Chicago
item.description: A new report from a police department outside of Chicago sheds light on a rare battery charge brought against an ICE agent after a fight with an activist.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim
item.media:credit: Carlos Javier Ortiz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered near an immigration detention center in Broadview, Ill., to protest ICE raids nationwide earlier this month.

item.title: Google co-founder had long relationship with Maxwell and visited Epstein’s island.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Sergey Brin at a private dinner for technology and business leaders at the White House, hosted by President Trump, in September.

item.title: Trump Officials Bypass Congress to Push Billions in Weapons Aid to Israel
item.description: The move was the third time the Trump administration has tried to expedite arms shipments to Israel by going around the review process for weapons sales.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters
item.media:description: The weapons aid included Apache attack helicopters and combat land vehicles.

item.title: Release of Three Million Epstein Pages Falls Short, Survivors Say
item.description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, told reporters on Friday that “there’s a hunger or a thirst for information that I do not think will be satisfied by the review of these documents.”
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Michael Gold and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press
item.media:description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, addressed reporters after the Justice Department released more Epstein files.

item.title: After Bovino Leaves, Minnesotans Search for Signs of Change in Crackdown
item.description: Arrests were continuing, according to residents who have tracked the immigration crackdown in the Twin Cities, but some people observed fewer clashes.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agents stopped a car in Minneapolis on Thursday.

item.title: Epstein contacted women for Steve Tisch, co-owner of the Giants.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Adam Hunger/Associated Press
item.media:description: Steve Tisch, co-owner of the New York Giants, in New York, in 2021.

item.title: F.B.I. Presentation Outlines Allegations Against Powerful Men
item.description: A 21-page slide presentation summarized the agency’s investigations into Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Matthew Goldstein and Steve Eder

item.title: 6 Missing as Search Continues for Boat Off the Coast of Massachusetts
item.description: Searchers recovered one body after the Lily Jean, a 72-foot fishing vessel, issued an emergency alert on Friday morning, the U.S. Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: David Goldman/Associated Press
item.media:description: A fishing boat that left from Gloucester, Mass., on Friday was reported missing off the coast of Massachusetts, the U.S. Coast Guard said.

item.title: Trump Officials Move to Double Number of H-2B Guest Visas This Year
item.description: It was a rare move by the Trump administration to expand a foreign worker program, amid a sweeping effort to drastically cut immigration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Giorgio Viera/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A landscaper working outside Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club and residence, in Palm Beach, Fla., in 2022. Mr. Trump has used the H-2B visa program to hire cooks, housekeepers and waiters at his properties.

item.title: Trump Called for ‘De-Escalation’ in Minneapolis. It Didn’t Last Long.
item.description: President Trump has offered dueling messages on the crisis in Minneapolis, part of a pattern of dialing back his rhetoric only to change again if the political winds are shifting.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About the Millions of Pages of Epstein Documents
item.description: Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche signaled that this would be the last major release of files related to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Justice Department released millions of new pages related to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Epstein Offered Prince Andrew a Meeting With a Russian Woman, Emails Show
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was stripped of his royal titles last year after new disclosures showed the extent of his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Britain’s former Prince Andrew at the Sandringham estate in England in 2022.

item.title: After ICE Took Liam Conejo Ramos, 2 Students From Same School Enter Detention
item.description: The school’s principal said he brought two children to federal custody at the request of their mother, who was detained. Last week, another student, Liam Conejo Ramos, was picked up by immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Seth Herald/Reuters
item.media:description: Valley View Elementary School in Columbia Heights, Minn., last week. Over two dozen parents and caregivers tied to the school have been detained in the Trump administration’s immigration sweeps.

item.title: What to Know About the ‘Abortion Clinic’ Law Being Used to Charge Don Lemon
item.description: The Trump administration used a federal law prohibiting blockades of abortion clinics and places of worship to charge Mr. Lemon and others in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Madeleine Hordinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: An anti-abortion protest outside a women’s health clinic in Bristol, Va., in 2023. The Trump administration has repurposed a 1994 law that was used to shield women’s health clinics from disruptive blockades.

item.title: ‘Don’t hang yourself,’ Epstein’s cellmate told him, according to prosecutor’s handwritten notes.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan. Jeffrey Epstein was found dead at the jail in 2019.

item.title: Senate Passes Deal to Fund Government and Negotiate ICE Limits
item.description: Democrats agreed to fund the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while they negotiate with President Trump on restricting his immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Minneapolis on Friday. The Senate passed a spending package to continue funding the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while Democrats negotiate with President Trump on restrictions to the administration’s immigration enforcement measures.

item.title: Judge Weighs Trump’s Removal of Slavery Markers From George Washington’s House
item.description: The administration has ordered that further changes be made to Independence National Historical Park, according to internal National Park Service documents obtained by The New York Times
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blank walls where signs about slavery were removed from Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia last week.

item.title: Protesters Denounce Trump Immigration Tactics in ‘National Shutdown’
item.description: Demonstrators rallied across the country, leaving school and work and closing businesses in a show of solidarity with Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao, Orlando Mayorquín, Nate Schweber, Rhianwen Watkins and Mark Bonamo
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in Foley Square in downtown Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: ICE Expands Power of Agents to Arrest People Without Warrants
item.description: An internal memo changed the standard from whether people are unlikely to show up for hearings to whether they could leave the scene.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents attempted to raid a home in Minneapolis earlier this week.

item.title: Escape to Alcatraz: Coyote Swims a Mile in Search of New Turf
item.description: The coyote struggled onto the rocky shore this month. It is the first documented coyote on Alcatraz since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coyote swam ashore at Alcatraz Island this month. It is the first documented coyote presence there since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.

item.title: Musk and Epstein Exchanged Emails About Visiting One Another, Documents Show
item.description: Mr. Musk has tried to put distance between himself and the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, but emails show the two were on friendly terms.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Sharon LaFraniere and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk at the Kennedy Center in Washington in November.

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Push Fractures Republican Party
item.description: The party was mostly unified on the issue not long ago, but splinters are everywhere now.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against I.R.S. Creates ‘Enormous Conflict of Interest’
item.description: The president is demanding that the federal government pay him at least $10 billion over the unauthorized disclosure of his tax returns during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump created what legal experts called an unparalleled situation of federal agencies facing a lawsuit from the head of the executive branch.

item.title: Emails Show Warm Relationship Between Epstein and Richard Branson
item.description: The two men’s relationship was known, and a photo of Mr. Branson had been on display in Mr. Epstein’s Upper East Side townhouse.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: U.S. Justice Department
item.media:description: Richard Branson, left, and Jeffrey Epstein in an undated image released by the Justice Department in December.

item.title: Bruce Springsteen Takes the Stage as Minneapolis Residents Take to the Streets
item.description: For a second week, residents demonstrated against Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s incursion into their city. And Bruce Springsteen made a surprise appearance at a benefit concert.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators poured into central Minneapolis for the second Friday in a row.

item.title: NASCAR Star’s Plane Had Several Instrument Failures Before Crash
item.description: The successive problems appeared to overwhelm the pilots, who were experienced but not authorized to fly the type of jet they were operating alone, according to federal safety investigators.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: NTSB, via Reuters
item.media:description: National Transportation Safety Board investigators examining the wreckage of a Cessna jet that crashed and killed former NASCAR driver Greg Biffle in Statesville, N.C., last month.

item.title: Dan McQuade, a Catalyst in Cosby’s Downfall, Dies at 43
item.description: His viral video of the comedian Hannibal Buress calling Bill Cosby a rapist helped spur broader coverage of sexual-assault accusations against a once-beloved entertainer.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Some Republicans Lament the Spending Deal Trump Has Blessed
item.description: Hard-right Republicans have criticized an agreement they see as capitulating to Democrats on their party’s strongest issue: immigration.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Friday.

item.title: Florida Universities Partnered With ICE, Stoking Anxiety Among Students
item.description: It is rare for schools to work in concert with immigration officials, and it remains unclear if the partnerships have led to deportations.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Martina Tuaty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Florida International University is one of 16 public universities around the state that have agreed to cooperate with ICE in recent years.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell appeared to receive a chummy missive in 2002 from a ‘Melania.’
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein’s longtime companion and the future first lady, Melania Trump, were known to have socialized together in that period.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Patrick McMullan, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo showing Jeffrey Epstein with Ghislaine Maxwell, right, and Carol Mack, left, at a 1995 event in New York City featured in a 2002 New York magazine profile of Mr. Epstein. Ms. Maxwell appeared to receive an email from a “Melania” complimenting her on the photo.

item.title: Feds Release Document of Tips Mentioning Trump and Epstein
item.description: This summer, federal investigators assembled a summary of accusations against Mr. Trump that had come in through the agency’s public tip line. The Times has not corroborated the allegations.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump was mentioned in more than a dozen tips received by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Epstein Notes Suggested Bill Gates Engaged in Extramarital Sex
item.description: It is unclear if Mr. Epstein sent the July 2013 emails to the Microsoft founder. A representative of the Gates Foundation said their claims were “absolutely absurd and completely false.”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill Gates, the Microsoft co-founder, was mentioned in two emails from Jeffrey Epstein released by the Justice Department on Friday.

item.title: Minnesota and Immigration Dominate 9 Mayors’ Discussion Over Safety and Trust Under Trump
item.description: The nation’s mayors gathered in Washington this week, and Minneapolis has dominated the conversation.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady and Caroline Gutman
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times

item.title: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick Planned Trip to Epstein’s Island
item.description: Prominent people have been scrutinized for their visits to Jeffrey Epstein’s island in the Caribbean. Mr. Lutnick’s visit had not been previously disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Michael Rothfeld
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick emailed Jeffrey Epstein in 2012 trying to visit him for a meal in the Caribbean, according to documents released by the Justice Department.

item.title: Texas May Be Losing Its Grip as America’s Fastest-Growing State
item.description: Long accustomed to rapid growth, Texas saw the overall number of people moving from other states sink to its lowest level in two decades, census estimates show.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Jeff Adelson
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Stockyards in Fort Worth. A slowdown in population growth is more pronounced in Texas than in any other state except Florida, the Census Bureau estimates.

item.title: How Did This Beloved Rock From Canada End Up in California?
item.description: Climbers have used the 70-pound rock, which they call Portable, to practice balancing and gripping. Months after it went missing, it was found 19 hours away.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: Federal Authorities Mapped Out Epstein’s Inner Circle
item.description: Only one person depicted or referred to in the chart as a potential co-conspirator, Ghislaine Maxwell, was ever charged with helping Mr. Epstein engage in sex trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein

item.title: How The Times Is Covering the Latest Release of Epstein Files
item.description: Several reporters and editors have covered the case since 2019. Others report on the Justice Department, Congress, the White House and the federal court system.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Texas A&M Ends Women’s Studies and Overhauls Hundreds of Classes on Race and Gender
item.description: New policies limiting the teaching of race and gender issues led administrators and professors to change hundreds of courses. School leaders say the rules could hurt A&M’s reputation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas A&M University’s new policy to limit teaching about race and gender has led to debates on campus about academic freedom.

item.title: Justice Dept. Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Killing of Alex Pretti
item.description: The announcement marked a significant reversal in the department’s approach to Mr. Pretti’s killing.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Alex Pretti, an intensive care nurse who was killed in Minneapolis by federal immigration agents.

item.title: Epstein Documents Include Many Uncorroborated Tips
item.description: The F.B.I. receives a huge volume of tips, and descriptions of them generally do not offer indications of the credibility of any claim.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press

item.title: Car Hits High School Student in Nebraska During an Anti-ICE Protest
item.description: A video showed a driver with a “Trump 2024” flag mounted to the car’s rear window driving into a girl who was holding a poster.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: David Golbitz/Fremont Tribune
item.media:description: Students at Fremont High School in Fremont, Neb., protesting on Thursday. One of the students was hit by a car that had a “Trump 2024” flag on its rear window.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Michael Gold and Alan Feuer

item.title: Who Is Georgia Fort, the Other Journalist Arrested Over a Church Protest?
item.description: Ms. Fort was taken into custody by federal agents Friday morning, following a grand jury indictment.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Cities Church in St. Paul, Minn., where protesters disrupted services this month. At least two journalists, Georgia Fort and Don Lemon, were arrested in connection with the protest.

item.title: Stock Market Takes Kevin Warsh’s Fed Nomination in Stride
item.description: Stock and bond markets were unfazed by Kevin Warsh’s nomination as the next Fed chair, with the S&P 500 lower on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Who Is Kevin Warsh, Trump’s Pick to Lead the Fed?
item.description: The president’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve is a financier and former governor of the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alastair Grant
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh is President Trump’s nominee to be chairman of the Federal Reserve.
